channel.title: Hackers attack LHC
channel.description:
The scientists behind the £4.4bn atom smasher had already received threatening emails and been besieged by telephone calls from worried members of the public concerned by speculation that the machine could trigger a black hole to swallow the earth, or earthquakes and tsunamis, despite endless reassurances to the contrary from the likes of Prof Stephen Hawking. Now it has emerged that, as the first particles were circulating in the machine near Geneva, a Greek group had hacked into the facility and displayed a page with the headline "GST: Greek Security Team." The people responsible signed off: "We are 2600 - dont mess with us. (sic)" The website - cmsmon.cern.ch - can no longer be accessed by the public as a result of the attack.
ahahahaha Shit, forgot the source: http://www.telegraph.co.uk/earth/main.jhtml?view=DETAILS&grid=&xml=/earth/2008/09/12/scicern212.xml

item.title: Hackers attack LHC
item.dc:creator: @FastBallz FastBawlz
item.description:
@FastBallz wrote:

[quote=“Greeny, post:13, topic:230869”]I can’t understand why the fuck something so important with no need for the internet would be connected to it.

Surly everything to do with the actual machine would just be on an internal network.[/quote]

They NEED internet. CERN doesn’t have enough processing power to calculate all of the information they receive, so send the information to other super computers around Europe and to people doing LHC@home.

& so the scientists can work from home

Read full topic

item.title: Hackers attack LHC
item.dc:creator: @XxKanexX Kane.
item.description:
@XxKanexX wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:11, topic:230869”][quote author=Kane. link=topic=303971.msg2439033#msg2439033 date=1221361556]
They should have kept it secret from the public until the final test… If possible.
Then everyone would see the world wasn’t platter to a black hole, no-one would try and hack them, and so on.
[/quote]

How do you keep a multi-billion dollar project with thousands of scientists and workers working on it secret? It seems like it would have been easier to keep up with security updates.[/quote]
Yeah, i understand that, hence; “If possible”
And the whole 30 years of construction would be a difficult time frame to not say anything.

These people are smart, wouldn’t they already be up to date with security? Yet, they still got hacked. It’s a little frightening considering the power of this machine and how vulnerable it is to intruders.

Read full topic
